problemStatement.formal: \forall n \in \mathbb{Z}, \quad n > 5 \land n \text{ odd} \implies \exists p_1, p_2, p_3 \text{ prime}: n = p_1 + p_2 + p_3
problemStatement.plain: Every odd integer greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three prime numbers.

proven: Vinogradov (1937): true for sufficiently large odd n
Helfgott (2013): true for all odd n > 5
open: Formal verification of full proof (requires circle method)
knownResults.goal: Formalize as much as tractable without circle method

currentState.focus: Built Decidable instances for both ternary and binary Goldbach

knowledge.progressSummary: Verified ternary Goldbach for n=7-101 (48 cases) and binary Goldbach for n=4-50 (24 cases). Built Decidable instances for both IsSumOfThreePrimes and IsSumOfTwoPrimes enabling `decide` tactic proofs. Proved structural reduction: Binary Goldbach => Weak Goldbach.

insights: Pattern `use p, q, r; refine <...> <;> decide` works for small primes
Decidable instances enable `decide` tactic: example : IsSumOfThreePrimes 7 := by decide
O(n^3) brute force search is practical for small n via isSumOfThreePrimesDecide
Structural reduction shows weak Goldbach follows from binary Goldbach for even n-3
Nat.Prime has DecidablePred instance enabling computational primality checks
nextSteps: Use native_decide for faster verification of larger numbers
State Vinogradov bound with explicit N0 ~ 10^1346

approaches.name: Decidable instances + explicit witnesses
approaches.strategy: Build Decidable instance, verify cases via decide tactic
risks: Limited to small n without circle method
